snippet: New York City is budgeting $22 million to try to save the Broad Channel neighborhood by installing bulkheads and by raising streets and sidewalks by three feet.
abstract: New York City is budgeting $22 million to help save Broad Channel, Queens, by installing bulkheads and raising streets and sidewalks; area’s vulnerability was exposed during Hurricane Sandy, which toppled homes into the bay, some of which still lie in ruins along the beach; project is part of Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's $20 billion plan to protect city’s 520 miles of coast over the next decade from rising sea levels.
lead_paragraph: New York City is budgeting $22 million to try to save the Broad Channel neighborhood by installing bulkheads and by raising streets and sidewalks by three feet.

headline.main: Where Streets Flood With the Tide, a Debate Over City Aid
headline.print_headline: Where Streets Flood With the Tide, a Debate Over City Aid
